div.p: Greetings. I received your letters, honorable compater, sent through Mr. Claudius Mey. Today, the deacons were gathered; however, I do not know what was decided. This messenger is immediately sent to Zurich.

I was in Solothurn these days; for I was accompanying my mother. While passing through, I encountered the interpreter of the king's envoy, who is stationed there. He told the young man traveling with me (who is a relative of his) that it was written to his lord that the people of Zurich were armed against the people of the countryside. Although I know this to be false, I gather from it that they suspect something.
Would that we were finally freed from those blasphemous conditions of peace!

Regarding Calvin, I wrote seriously to Zebedee; I hope that we will settle this matter. I wish to see what he wrote against Westphal; the subscription will be difficult for us to obtain due to the various corrupt judgments of those judging; however, I do not know what will happen yet.

In Augsburg, the Lutherans are in great conflict with our people. The people of Ulm have driven out the Interimists along with the papists; Frecht hopes to return there. They would like to have ministers from the Swiss; but I fear that Frecht will dissuade them; for I seem to sense this.
The wife of Johann Jakob Fugger has died; no papist funeral rites were celebrated for her; but as she departed in the true confession of faith, only Christian rites were performed for her.

There is nothing else new. Emanuel Tremellius has written a catechism in the Hebrew language, which you will see shortly. All of ours greet you, and we also wish well-being for your entire family along with the brothers and fellow ministers, our esteemed lords. In Bern, on the first of November, 1554.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zurich, his honorable lord and compater.
